summary: In this chapter, Sarah Knight emphasizes that the problem with an overflowing inbox often lies not in the volume of incoming emails but in personal sending habits. She encourages readers to reflect on their email habits, suggesting that unnecessary emails can lead to wasted time and stress. By consolidating communication, choosing brevity, and opting for direct conversation methods, individuals can significantly reduce the number of messages sent. Knight outlines practical techniques for more efficient emailing, ultimately advocating for mindfulness in communication. This approach allows for a clearer inbox and a more organized mindset.

slides.section_title: IT’S NOT THE SIZE OF THE INBOX, IT’S HOW YOU USE IT
slides.section_body: Having a mountain of emails is not an excuse for being disorganized. The real issue lies in how we manage the email we receive. Most of us have more emails than we can handle, but it's about our systems and habits. Efficient email management is key to overcoming this overwhelm.
slides.quote: Too many emails? It’s not about the volume, it’s about your management.

slides.section_body: Consider your outbox as a source of your inbox woes. Are you guilty of sending unnecessary emails out of boredom or procrastination? Reflect on whether your messages are truly necessary before hitting send.
slides.quote: Cut off the problem at the source: your sending habits.

slides.section_body: Before typing that quick 'hello' or sharing unimportant musings, ask yourself if this message needs to be sent. Often, the answer is 'no'. You can save valuable time and avoid creating unnecessary email threads.
slides.quote: Does this even matter? Half the time, it doesn’t.

slides.section_body: Consolidate your emails. Instead of sending multiple messages throughout the day, create a draft and add to it. This not only minimizes emails but helps clarify your thoughts and questions for better communication.
slides.quote: Send fewer emails by combining messages into one.

slides.section_body: Sometimes, an impromptu phone call or quick chat can convey more than a long email chain. Don't be afraid to switch it up and have a direct conversation.
slides.quote: Pick up the phone — it might save you time.

slides.section_body: Avoid drowning recipients in lengthy emails. Stick to the important information and keep your messages brief. This increases the likelihood that your emails will be read and acted upon.
slides.quote: Brevity is the soul of effective communication.

slides.section_body: When crafting your emails, pose your key question right at the start. This helps you get straight to the point and may help you realize you don’t need to say much more.
slides.quote: Ask the most important question upfront.

slides.section_body: Establish a sense of urgency at the beginning of your emails without sounding aggressive. Clear and informative language sets the tone for responses.
Consider the effectiveness of your communication after the fact. If people aren't responding as desired, take a step back and reassess how you present your messages.

Effective email management can significantly alleviate stress and improve productivity. Mindful communication is essential, leading to a clearer and more organized life. Embrace these strategies to gain control over your inbox.
slides.quote: Manage your emails wisely and enjoy a stress-free inbox.
